statement.text: The smallest forces measured are in the attonewton (10⁻¹⁸ N) to zeptonewton (10⁻²¹ N) range, achieved using optical tweezers, atomic force microscopy (AFM), and nanomechanical resonators. Thermal noise sets a fundamental limit: F_thermal = √(4k_B T γ Δf) where γ is damping. The Casimir force between surfaces (~10⁻¹² N/m² × area) and single-molecule forces (~pN) are routinely measured. The Planck force (~10⁴⁴ N) is NOT a minimum—it's enormous, the force where gravitational binding energy equals rest mass energy.
statement.formal: Thermal limit: F_n = √(4k_B T κ Δf / Q) for resonator; Best achieved: ~10⁻²¹ N (zeptonewton); AFM: ~10⁻¹² N (pN); Optical tweezers: ~10⁻¹³ N (100 fN)

explanation.intuition: Force measurements are limited by thermal fluctuations—random kicks from surrounding molecules. Reducing temperature and using high-Q resonators minimizes this noise. The smallest forces detected are from quantum vacuum fluctuations (Casimir), single atoms, and gravitational effects on nanoscale objects. The Planck force is NOT minimum—it's the force that compresses a Planck mass into a Planck volume, creating a black hole.
explanation.key_insight: Force sensitivity depends on: (1) Mechanical compliance (softer springs give larger deflections), (2) Quality factor Q (high Q reduces thermal noise), (3) Temperature (lower T means less thermal motion). Best force sensors: optical tweezers (~fN), high-Q nanomechanical resonators (~aN-zN), torsion balances for gravity (~fN). Standard quantum limit: F_SQL = √(2ℏκ·Δf) for spring constant κ.
explanation.technical_details: Optical tweezers trap particles with ~pN/nm stiffness, detecting fN forces on microspheres. Carbon nanotube resonators achieve zeptonewton sensitivity. Casimir force ~10⁻⁸ N between 1 μm² plates at 100 nm separation. LIGO detects gravitational wave forces ~10⁻¹⁸ N on 40 kg mirrors. Single kinesin motor generates ~6 pN.

comparison_with_planck.interpretation: Planck force is enormous—the gravitational attraction of two Planck masses at one Planck length. It equals the tension of cosmic strings in some models.

related.relationship: Planck force is NOT minimum—it's 10⁴⁴ N

learning_objectives: Understand thermal noise as force measurement limit

common_misconceptions: Planck force is NOT minimum—it's enormous (10⁴⁴ N)
Force resolution depends on temperature and Q factor
There is no fundamental minimum force—just noise limits
